item.title: Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 Delayed to October 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/vampire-masquerade-bloodlines-2-delayed-october-2025

Paradox and developer The Chinese Room have announced that Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 has been delayed yet again. It's now set to come out later this year.

In a new development update trailer, World of Darkness executive VP Marco Behrmann reveals that Bloodlines 2 won't be meeting its previously-announced release window; the game was set to come out in the first half of this year.

However, the two aforementioned studios believe that "ensuring great technical quality is more important than sticking to a specific date", and so they've admitted that Bloodlines 2 "will not be ready for release" before the fall.

According to Behrmann, however, the game is "done", and The Chinese Room and Paradox are currently focusing on bug fixing and testing, placing Bloodlines 2 in a "late development stage".

The developer is apparently currently working to "ensure [Bloodlines 2] is stable and free of bugs that could disrupt the player experience", hopefully guaranteeing that the game "meets the technical quality standards that [fans] rightfully expect and deserve".

As such, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 will now be launching in October 2025, although Behrmann stopped short of announcing a new release date for the game. The wait goes on, it seems.

In case you're unfamiliar, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 has a very long and arduous development history. The game was first announced back in 2019, at which point original game writer Brian Mitsoda was set to return.

After numerous delays, Mitsoda was removed from the project, and its future was relatively uncertain until the game returned in late 2023, now being developed by Dear Esther and Everybody's Gone to the Rapture studio The Chinese Room.

We can only hope that this new release window for Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 is accurate, but given the game's long and storied history, I will believe that when I see it. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Popular Guessing Game GeoGuessr Comes to Steam in April
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/geoguessr-steam-april

Popular geographical guessing game GeoGuessr is making its way to Steam, so you'll soon be able to completely fail to guess where on earth a random muddy field is through Valve's platform.

Per a post on X, the game will be launching via Steam Early Access sometime in April, and the Early Access version will include both Solo Duels and Unranked Team Duels.

Playing Unranked Team Duels will be free, but the Solo Duels mode will require a GeoGuessr Steam Pass. If you've got a subscription on the browser version of the game, that won't translate to the Steam edition, so you'll have to fork out some more cash if you want to play Solo Duels on Steam.

You won't be able to use your GeoGuessr browser account to play the game on Steam; it's technically a new game, so it'll require a new account as well, although it sounds like you'll just be able to use your regular Steam profile.

You will, however, be able to access crossplay between GeoGuessr on Steam and the browser version of the game, so even if your buddies aren't playing via Steam, you should still be able to play with (or against!) them.

If you do intend to play Solo Duels, you'll rise through the ranks gradually in order to prove yourself as a GeoGuessr champion. It promises to be exactly as addictive as the regular browser version of the game.

If you're not familiar with GeoGuessr, the clue is in the name; it's a game that shows you a random picture from somewhere around the world, and it's up to you to use context clues (or just wild guesses) to figure out where the picture might show.

You'll be able to check out GeoGuessr on Steam when it launches via Early Access sometime in April. If you'd like, you can wishlist the game now to keep up with its progress on Steam.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds Title Update 1 Release Date Revealed for Next Week
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/monster-hunter-wilds-title-update-1-release-date

Capcom has announced the release date for the upcoming Monster Hunter Wilds Title Update 1, which is set to introduce a new (or perhaps that should be returning) monster and more to the game next week.

Per a new Monster Hunter showcase that aired earlier today, Title Update 1 will arrive on Friday, April 4th. The main attraction when it comes to this update is the introduction of Mizutsune, a water monster that made its first appearance in 2016's 3DS game Monster Hunter Generations.

You'll need to be High Rank level 21 or over to take on Mizutsune, and once you reach this level, you'll be able to grab an Extra Mission after speaking with Kanya in the Scarlet Forest. That's the mission in which Mizutsune waits for you.

It's not just Mizutsune that's coming as part of this update, of course. You can also look forward to battling a new Arch-tempered version of new monster Rey Dau, which will be added to the game in a new quest "at a later date".

Zoh Shia, another new monster introduced in Monster Hunter Wilds, can now be fought as part of repeatable quests, although you will need to complete a new HR 50 mission in order to access it.

If you're looking for a new hangout spot for you and your fellow hunters, then you can head over to the new Grand Hub, which serves as a place "for hunters to gather and socialize", according to Capcom. There's also a fun new minigame to try out there.

You can check out all of the highlights of Monster Hunter Wilds Title Update 1 right here courtesy of Capcom, and you can take a look at a brand new trailer for the update below.

Monster Hunter Wilds is the latest game in Capcom's long-running Monster Hunter series. It's proven to be the most popular game in the franchise by far, hitting eight million sales in just three days and breaking records both for the series and for Capcom as a whole on Steam.

You can pick up Monster Hunter Wilds right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. If you want to know what our Tyler thought of the game, you can see his review here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
